narrative: I pushed the injection button and held it for 10 seconds like the instructions say, but when I pulled the needle out, a huge stream of medicine squirted out of the pen tip. It clearly didn't deliver the full dose during the injection.
reasoning: Failure to deliver full dose/mechanical lag.

narrative: The pharmacy dispensed a box to me that expires next month. Since I'm supposed to get a three-month supply, the last two pens in the box will be expired before I even get a chance to use them. This is poor inventory management.
reasoning: Inadequate dating for the duration of the prescription.

narrative: There's something wrong with the dose counter display on my pen. When I look at the little window that's supposed to show you what dose you've dialed and how many doses remain, it's completely blank. Just empty, white or gray space - no numbers visible at all. I've tried looking at it in bright light, in sunlight, with my reading glasses, and there are just no numbers showing. The pen otherwise seems to function - the dial turns and clicks like it should, the solution looks clear and normal - but I have absolutely no way to verify what dose I'm setting or confirm how many doses are left in the pen. The dose counter is a critical safety feature because you need to know you're getting the right amount of medication and track when the pen will be empty. Without being able to see the numbers, I can't safely use this pen. I don't know if the printing somehow got missed during manufacturing, or if there's an internal mechanism that's supposed to display the numbers that's broken. Either way, it's a device malfunction that makes the pen unusable. Pharmacy replaced it and documented the issue. The one they gave me as a replacement has a perfectly clear, readable dose counter like it's supposed to.
reasoning: Non-functional dose counter prevents proper dose verification and tracking of remaining doses.

narrative: The spring inside the pen made a loud 'twang' sound when I was dialing the dose, and now the button is stuck halfway down. I can't push it in or pull it out. The whole mechanism feels like it's collapsed inside.

I've been on the 1 mg dose for a month now and I'm actually gaining weight. My blood sugar numbers are higher than they were when I was on the 0.5 mg dose from a different batch. It feels like this entire box of pens is just water or has no active medicine in it.
reasoning: Lack of expected clinical effect suggesting low potency.

narrative: I'm experiencing some unusual mechanical issues with this pen that have me concerned it might fail completely. When I turn the dose selector dial to set my dose, the mechanism is working - the dial turns and the dose counter advances properly - but something doesn't sound or feel right. The internal mechanism is making these grinding or clicking sounds that are much louder than I'm used to hearing. My previous pens have always been smooth and quiet when turning the dial, maybe a subtle click but nothing loud. This one sounds rough, almost like gears grinding against each other or something. And it doesn't just sound different, it feels different too. There's more resistance when turning, and the motion isn't smooth - it's kind of rough and catches slightly as you turn it. I compared it to an older pen I still have and the difference is really noticeable. I'm worried that whatever is causing this abnormal sound and rough operation is going to get worse and the mechanism might fail completely mid-way through using the pen. Like maybe some internal gear or component is wearing down or misaligned. I can still use it for now since the dose counter is advancing correctly, but I'm keeping a close eye on it and I contacted the pharmacy to let them know. They said to keep using it but monitor it closely, and if it gets worse or stops working properly to bring it in immediately. They documented the lot number in case this turns out to be a batch issue with component quality.
reasoning: Abnormal mechanical sounds and rough operation indicate internal component degradation.

narrative: I pressed the button to inject, but the plunger didn't move at all. The counter stayed at 0.5 mg. I tried again, pressing much harder, and still nothing. The device is completely unresponsive even though I followed the priming steps.

This is strange and I'm not sure what to make of it. I have two pens from the same carton, same lot number, and both of them have an unusual marking inside the cartridge. When you look at the glass cartridge that holds the solution, there's this ring-shaped mark or stain on the inner glass surface, roughly in the middle of the cartridge. It's not in the solution itself - the solution appears clear - but you can see it on the inside wall of the glass. Looks like some kind of residue or discoloration that formed a ring around the inside circumference. At first I thought maybe it was just a reflection or something on the outside of the glass, but when I look carefully and turn the pen, it's definitely on the inner surface. Both pens from the same carton have this same marking. My previous pens from other batches never had any marks or discoloration on the glass at all. The cartridge glass has always been perfectly clear inside and out. I'm concerned this could be residue from the filling process, or discoloration from the medication degrading and depositing something on the glass, or maybe even contamination. The solution itself looks clear, but having visible residue or staining on the container interior is not normal and makes me question whether the product is okay to use. Brought them to the pharmacy and they agreed the markings are unusual and shouldn't be there. They're replacing both pens and sending them to the manufacturer to investigate what caused the staining.
reasoning: Residue or staining on container interior indicates contamination from manufacturing process.

narrative: The pharmacy gave me a pen today that expires in less than a week. I'm supposed to use this over the next month. They shouldn't be dispensing stock that is this close to its expiration date for a multi-week treatment.
reasoning: Dispensing product with inadequate shelf life remaining.

narrative: I've been taking the 1 mg dose, but my morning blood sugar levels are higher than they were on the 0.5 mg dose from a different batch. It feels like this entire lot has very little of the active ingredient in it.
reasoning: Suspected lack of potency based on clinical data.

narrative: I tried to dial the dose to 0.5 mg but the knob is stuck. It won't turn past 0.25 mg. I've tried applying more force but I don't want to break it. It clicks but won't advance. This is a brand new pen.

When I try to press the injection button, it feels like there's something blocking it internally. It takes an incredible amount of force to get it to budge, and even then, it only moves a tiny bit before getting stuck again. I'm afraid I'm not getting the full dose because the mechanism just isn't advancing the plunger correctly.
reasoning: Mechanical resistance in the injection button.

narrative: My blood sugar usually drops very predictably after my shot, but with this batch, my numbers have stayed exactly where they were when I wasn't on any medication at all. It's like I'm injecting a placebo.
reasoning: Lack of efficacy suggesting zero or low potency.

narrative: I received a recall notice for this lot number. They said there might be glass particles in the solution. I checked and I have two pens from this lot. I need to return them.
reasoning: Recall due to glass particulate risk.

narrative: The pen cap was glued on. I had to use pliers to get it off. It left glue residue on the needle attachment. I can't use it safely.

The outer carton was completely smashed on one side when I picked it up. When I opened it, the pen itself has a visible crack in the clear plastic window area. I'm worried that the vacuum seal of the medication might be broken or that it might leak everywhere when I try to use it.
reasoning: Physical damage to the primary container.

narrative: I've been taking this for months but this new box isn't working. My appetite is back and my sugar is high. I think this batch has no active ingredient. It's a dud.

The tamper-evident seal on the side of the box was already slit open when I got it. The pen inside looked okay, but the fact that the seal was broken makes me worry that someone might have swapped the pen or tampered with the contents.

I opened the box and the pen was sitting in a pool of liquid. The cap was wet and when I took it off, I could see fluid leaking from the cartridge. It smells like insulin or medicine. I haven't used it but half the liquid is gone. I think the cartridge is cracked.

My order was delayed in the mail and when it finally arrived after 5 days, the ice packs had completely melted and the pens were room temperature. The thermal indicator inside the box was red, confirming it got too warm.
reasoning: Temperature excursion during transit due to delay.

narrative: As I was dialing the dose, the dial suddenly snapped and started spinning freely in both directions without clicking. It won't stay on the 0.5 mg setting at all. The internal ratchet must have broken. Now I have no way to select my dose.
reasoning: Mechanical failure of the dose dial.

narrative: I found out my pharmacy was storing these pens in a regular cabinet because their fridge was full. They told me it was 'fine for a few days', but the manufacturer's label specifically says they must be refrigerated before first use.
reasoning: Improper storage conditions at the retail level.

narrative: The pen I received from the pharmacy today has an expiration date that passed six months ago. I can't believe they didn't catch this before handing it over to me. It's a huge oversight by the distribution team.

I ordered my Ozempic through the mail order pharmacy that my insurance requires, and when the shipment arrived yesterday I was immediately concerned. The package was just a regular cardboard shipping box with six pens inside - that's three months worth of medication for me. But here's the problem: there were no cold packing materials whatsoever. No ice packs, no gel packs, no insulated liner, nothing. Just the pens in their cartons sitting in a plain cardboard box. This medication is supposed to be kept refrigerated, right? And this is August, we're having temperatures in the high 80s and 90s every day. I checked the tracking information and the package was in transit for three full days from the distribution center to my house. Three days of unrefrigerated shipping in summer heat. There wasn't even a temperature monitoring indicator included to show whether it got too hot. How am I supposed to know if this medication is still good or if it's been sitting at 90 degrees for three days and is now degraded? The pharmacy instructions clearly state the product requires refrigerated shipping. I called the mail order pharmacy customer service and the rep seemed surprised, said there should definitely have been cold packing. She's opening an investigation into why the shipment went out improperly packed and they're sending a replacement with proper temperature control. But I have no confidence in using these pens that were shipped without any temperature control. This is a complete failure in their distribution process.
reasoning: Complete absence of temperature control during shipping for refrigerated medication.

narrative: There's a bunch of tiny white flakes at the bottom of the pen. They look like dandruff or little crystals. I tried shaking it gently to see if they would dissolve, but they just float around and then settle back down. It's definitely not a clear solution anymore.
The pharmacy gave me pens that expire next week. I need them for a month. They are trying to get rid of old stock. I refused them.
This expiry date is in a weird format. Day/Month/Year. It's confusing. Is it expired or not?

The box arrived with the top flap completely torn off and missing. The pen was still inside, but it was exposed to the elements and whoever handled the mail. I don't feel like the product's integrity was maintained.

I've lost all the progress I made on my A1C since starting this new box of pens. My doctor is confused why my numbers are spiked, and the only change is this new prescription. I think the medicine in these pens is degraded or inert.
reasoning: Clinical failure suggesting lack of potency.

narrative: I found a really concerning labeling discrepancy that makes me question which batch of medication I actually have. I was documenting my medication information for my records like I always do, and I noticed that the batch number printed on the actual pen body says batch U8537B. But when I looked at the batch number printed on the outer carton, it says T8537B. The first character is different - U on the pen, T on the carton. Everything else in the batch code is the same, and the expiry dates match between the pen and carton, but that first character difference is significant. Batch numbers are supposed to be unique identifiers for traceability purposes. If there's a recall or quality issue, you need to be able to identify exactly which batch a product came from. With the pen and carton showing different batch codes, there's no way to accurately trace this product. Is the pen from batch U or batch T? I called the pharmacy to ask about this discrepancy and the pharmacist couldn't explain it. She said it shouldn't happen and they're documenting it. I returned the pen because without accurate batch identification, I can't be confident about the product's provenance, quality testing, or whether it's even the right medication. This seems like a labeling error or mix-up during packaging where pens from one batch got put in cartons labeled for a different batch.
reasoning: Batch number discrepancy between device and carton prevents accurate traceability.

narrative: I checked the lot number on the manufacturer's website to verify the authenticity, and the system says that lot number doesn't exist. I'm really concerned because I've already used one of the pens from this box. This looks like a counterfeit batch.

My blood sugar usually drops within 24 hours of my shot, but this time it's stayed consistently high. I even checked the pen to make sure I actually injected, and the dose counter moved, but I'm just not feeling any of the usual effects. This batch feels very weak.

The medication in the pen has a strange, hazy look to it, like someone dropped a pinch of flour into water. It's not clear at all. I've used this brand for months and it's always been perfectly clear. I'm afraid to use this one because it looks unstable.

I ordered my Ozempic through mail order pharmacy like I usually do, and it was delivered this afternoon while I was at work. When I got home around six o'clock, the package was sitting on my front porch, and this is in the middle of July, we've had temperatures in the nineties all week. The first thing I noticed when I picked it up was that it felt warm, not cool like it should be. Opened it up right away and the ice pack or cold pack thing they include was completely melted, just a bag of water basically. And you know those temperature indicator stickers they put on the package? The one on mine was showing red, which according to the instructions means it got too warm. The tracking info shows it left the facility yesterday morning, so that means this medication has been sitting unrefrigerated for at least twelve hours, probably longer considering transit time and sitting on my porch in direct sunlight. I called the pharmacy right away and they're sending a replacement with better packaging, but I'm concerned about whether this medication is even good anymore. They said not to use it, which makes sense, but it's frustrating that their shipping process allowed this to happen.
reasoning: Documentation indicates excursion beyond labeled temperature range during transit.

narrative: I accidentally left the box of pens on the kitchen counter for 24 hours in a warm room before I realized they should have gone in the fridge. I know they're supposed to stay cold until they're first used.
reasoning: Patient error resulting in room-temp exposure.

narrative: This pen expired 6 months ago. The pharmacy still gave it to me. I noticed the date when I got home. This is negligent.

I'm calling on behalf of my 76-year-old mother who uses Ozempic for her diabetes. She's been on it for several months and was doing fine with the injections, but this new pen we picked up last week has a serious problem with the injection button. The button that you press to actually deliver the dose is extremely stiff - like, way too hard to press down. She has some arthritis in her hands and usually can manage the normal resistance, but this pen requires so much force that she literally cannot push the button all the way down to complete the injection. She tried using both thumbs pressing together as hard as she could, and it barely moves. I tried it myself and yes, it's much stiffer than it should be. The button should depress smoothly with moderate pressure, but this one seems to have some kind of mechanical problem that's making it almost impossible to push. This completely prevents her from being able to take her medication as directed, which is obviously a major issue for her diabetes management. We had to go back to the pharmacy and they tested it themselves and agreed something is wrong with the mechanism. They replaced it with a different pen that works normally. This seems like a pretty significant device malfunction that would affect anyone with any kind of hand strength issues, not just elderly patients.
reasoning: Excessive resistance in injection mechanism preventing dose completion indicates mechanical failure.

narrative: The expiration date is rubbed off the box. It looks like it was printed with bad ink. I can't tell when it expires. I don't want to use old medication.
I'm not losing any weight on this new batch. I'm hungry all the time. The previous pens worked great. I think this lot is weak.

The injection button is so stiff that my elderly mother can't press it down at all. I tried it myself and it requires a huge amount of pressure to move. This is a major design flaw or manufacturing defect for people with hand issues.
I accidentally left my pen in the car overnight and it froze. It's solid ice inside. I know I can't use it now. The instructions say do not freeze. It was 20 degrees last night.

I just realized that the dose counter on my pen only goes up to 0.5 mg, but the box it came in is clearly labeled as the 1 mg strength. The pharmacy label also says 1 mg. This mismatch is really confusing and I'm worried I've been underdosing myself for the last two weeks.
reasoning: Mismatch between device markings and carton labeling.

narrative: I found a box of these in the back of my cabinet that expired in 2022. I asked my pharmacist if I could still use them since they've been in the fridge, and they said absolutely not. I'm reporting this as a distribution concern because they were part of a bulk order.

The package sat in the sorting facility for four days during a record-breaking heatwave with no refrigeration. When it finally arrived, the ice packs were not just melted, they were actually warm. The pens were quite hot to the touch.

I'm a new patient just starting on Ozempic and when I got home with my prescription and opened the carton to read through everything before my first dose, I realized the patient information leaflet is completely missing. You know, that folded paper insert that's supposed to have all the instructions for use and important safety information? It's just not in the box at all. The carton had the pen and the needle tips but no paperwork whatsoever. This is my first time using this medication so I really needed those instructions. I drove back to the pharmacy and explained the situation to the pharmacist, and she was nice enough to photocopy the instruction leaflet from another box they had in stock so at least I'd have something to reference. But she said she's never seen one come without the insert before and that it should always be included. She filed a complaint or whatever they call it about the missing component. It makes me wonder what else might be wrong with that batch if they're missing basic packaging components like that. How many other people got boxes without instructions and maybe just tried to figure it out on their own without the proper safety information?
reasoning: Missing IFU insert is a packaging component defect affecting safe use.

narrative: The liquid is cloudy and milky. There are white clumps floating in it. It's supposed to be clear and colorless. I shook it but it didn't dissolve. It looks like the protein has precipitated out.
reasoning: Turbidity and precipitation indicating product degradation.

narrative: The tamper seal on the box was cut. Someone opened this before me. I don't trust it. The pharmacy needs to replace it.
The spring inside the pen broke and shot out the back when I tried to inject. The whole mechanism fell apart in my hands. It's completely broken.

The dose selector dial doesn't click anymore. It just spins loosely in both directions. I have no way of knowing if I've dialed up the correct dose because the mechanism isn't catching at the set points.
reasoning: Failure of dose selector ratchet mechanism.

narrative: My refrigerator froze everything last night. The Ozempic is frozen solid. The glass cartridge cracked from the ice expansion.

The batch number on this pen is part of a list of recalled lots I saw online due to concerns about the shelf life and stability. I called my pharmacy and they confirmed I should return them. It's a distribution failure.
reasoning: Product distributed from a recalled/unstable batch.

narrative: The box is labeled 0.25 mg but the pen inside has a 1 mg dial. I almost overdosed. This is a serious packaging error. The pharmacy gave me the sealed box.

I can see a tiny sliver of glass—it looks like a needle-thin shard—floating in the liquid near the stopper. I'm terrified that if I inject this, I'll be pushing glass into my body. This is a terrifying quality control failure.

The box says 'Store between 2C and 8C', but the pharmacy label stuck over it says 'Store at room temperature'. These instructions are contradictory and I don't know which one to follow to keep the medicine from spoiling.
I ordered from a website without a prescription. The pens arrived in a plain envelope with no ice. The label is in Spanish. I think I got scammed with fake medicine.
I bought this at a flea market stand. The guy said it was real. Now I'm looking at it and the logo is crooked. I think I made a bad decision.

This is really frustrating and potentially dangerous for new patients. I'm starting Ozempic for the first time and my doctor's office gave me careful instructions about how to use it, said to read all the information materials thoroughly, watch the injection technique video, all of that. So I get home with my prescription, open the carton, and pull out the patient information leaflet to read through it carefully before my first dose. Start reading it and something seems off - the information doesn't match what my doctor told me. Then I look at the front of the leaflet and realize it's for Victoza, which is liraglutide, not Ozempic which is semaglutide. It's a completely different medication in the same drug class. The pen itself is definitely Ozempic - I can see that clearly on the pen label. The outer carton is labeled Ozempic. But the instruction leaflet inside is for the wrong medication. The dosing instructions are different, the titration schedule is different, the pen device works differently. If I was a brand new patient who didn't know better, I could have followed the wrong instructions and taken incorrect doses or used the pen wrong. This is a serious labeling and packaging mix-up that creates a real risk of medication errors. The pharmacy was apologetic and gave me the correct Ozempic leaflet from another box, but they're reporting this because obviously the wrong inserts are getting packaged with the wrong products somewhere in their process.
reasoning: Wrong product insert is a labeling mix-up that creates risk of medication error.

narrative: There is a dark hair—it looks like a cat or dog hair—trapped inside the sealed glass cartridge along with the medication. This is a disgusting and serious breach of sterile manufacturing standards.

The pharmacy is constantly sending me pens that expire within 10 days of me receiving them. Since I only take one shot a week, I'm always using 'expired' medication by the time I get to the third or fourth pen. They need to manage their inventory better.

This is pretty concerning. I was setting up for my injection this morning, dialing my dose up to the 1.0 mg marking like my prescription says. I'm turning the dose selector dial and it's clicking normally, getting up to 1.0, and then suddenly I hear this loud snap sound from inside the pen. Like something broke inside. Immediately after that, the dose selector knob started spinning freely, just rotating without any resistance at all. No more clicking, no stopping at the dose markings, it just spins and spins continuously like the internal mechanism that controls it has completely disconnected or broken. Now I can't set any dose because the selector isn't engaging with anything. I can spin it all day and nothing happens, it doesn't lock into any position. Clearly something snapped or broke inside that's critical to the dose selection mechanism. The pen is basically completely unusable now. I'd only had this pen for a week and was on my second dose from it when this happened. Brought it to the pharmacy and they agreed it's an internal mechanical failure. They documented the lot number and are sending the pen back to the manufacturer to investigate what failed inside. They gave me a replacement but I'm nervous about whether the replacement might have the same defect if this was a batch issue.
reasoning: Internal mechanism failure with audible breakage preventing dose selection.

narrative: The foil seal on the pen cap was open. It's not sterile. I can't use it. It was like that in the box.

Something really strange and concerning happened with my injection last week. I'm on the starting dose of 0.25 mg, so I carefully dialed it to exactly that marking like I always do. But when I did the injection, something felt different. The plunger movement seemed to go on longer than usual, and there was this unusual resistance that I hadn't felt before. The whole injection took maybe twice as long as it normally does. I thought maybe I was just imagining things, but over the next few hours I started feeling really off - more nauseous than I've ever been on this medication, kind of shaky, just not right at all. Called my doctor's office and the nurse had me come in. My blood sugar was lower than expected and she was concerned that maybe I got more than the 0.25 mg dose I dialed. Like maybe the pen delivered more medication than what was showing on the dose selector. I had to monitor my blood sugar closely for the next day or so. I still have the pen and I'm afraid to use it again. The pharmacy is having me return it to send to the manufacturer for testing because if the dosing mechanism is off, that's a serious safety issue. The nurse said to document everything that happened in case the pen is found to be defective.
reasoning: Dosing mechanism delivered incorrect amount; device mechanical failure.

narrative: Usually, after I inject, I can feel the drug working within a day—my morning blood sugar is much lower. But with this new pen, my numbers are exactly the same as if I hadn't taken anything. I suspect this pen is defective or has no active ingredient.
The text on the label is smeared. I can't read the instructions or the dose. The ink isn't dry. It wipes off on my finger.

I'm having a mechanical problem with my pen that's preventing me from taking my doses properly. The injection button on the pen is working when I press it - it depresses normally and I can feel and hear the click that indicates the dose is being delivered. That part seems fine. But after I release pressure on the button, it doesn't spring back up to its original position like it's supposed to. Instead, it stays stuck down in the depressed position. Now I can't dial up my next dose because the button needs to be in the up position before the dose selector will turn, and it's stuck down. This happened after only my second dose from a brand new pen, which means there should be four more doses remaining that I now can't access. I've tried gently pulling on the button to see if it would pop back up, but it won't budge. There's clearly something wrong with the spring mechanism or whatever internal component is supposed to make the button reset after each injection. The pen is basically useless now after only two uses. Brought it to the pharmacy and they confirmed it's a device malfunction with the button reset mechanism. They replaced it and are sending the defective one back to the manufacturer. Seems like a pretty serious design or manufacturing defect if the button mechanism fails after just two doses.
reasoning: Button mechanism failure preventing proper reset and subsequent dose delivery.

narrative: The liquid has turned brown. It looks like tea. It's been in the fridge. I think it oxidized. It looks spoiled.

I use a mail order pharmacy for my Ozempic because it's cheaper than going to the local pharmacy, but this delivery was a disaster. The package was delivered yesterday afternoon while I was at work - it was left on my front porch at around one PM according to the delivery timestamp. I didn't get home until almost seven PM, so it had been sitting out there for about six hours. And yesterday was brutal - we had a heat advisory with temperatures over 95 degrees, and my porch gets direct sun all afternoon. When I picked up the package it felt warm, definitely not cool like refrigerated medication should be. Inside, the gel ice pack that's supposed to keep it cold was completely melted, just warm liquid at that point. And there was one of those temperature indicator strips on the inner packaging, and it clearly showed that the product had been exposed to high temperatures for an extended period. The indicator was red or orange, I forget exactly which, but either way it means the temperature got too high. According to the information sheet, this medication is supposed to stay refrigerated and prolonged heat exposure can make it ineffective or degraded. I called the mail order pharmacy customer service and after being on hold forever, they agreed to send a replacement overnight, but this is a waste of medication and it's concerning that their shipping methods allow this to happen. They need better insulated packaging or refrigerated shipping options, especially for summer deliveries.
reasoning: Extended high-temperature exposure during shipping exceeds storage specifications and may compromise efficacy.

narrative: I have a pen that I haven't used yet - it's still in the original packaging and has been kept in my refrigerator since I got it two weeks ago. Was looking at it today to prepare for starting it this week and noticed something concerning when I examined the solution. At the very bottom of the cartridge, there's this thick white sediment that's accumulated down there. It's definitely not normal - it looks almost pasty or gel-like, not like the clear liquid solution. I tried gently rolling the pen between my palms like the instructions say to do if you see particles, thinking maybe it would mix back in and dissolve. But even after rolling it for several minutes, the sediment stays clumped at the bottom. It doesn't redissolve or disperse back into the solution. The rest of the solution in the upper portion of the cartridge looks perfectly normal and clear, but this sediment at the bottom is just sitting there. The pen has been properly refrigerated the whole time - I keep my fridge temp between 36 and 40 degrees like you're supposed to. This isn't from improper storage on my end. It looks like the protein in the solution has separated out or aggregated or something. That's a sign of degradation, right? Obviously not using this pen. The pharmacy agreed this is abnormal appearance and they're replacing it. They said the manufacturer will want to test it to see what caused the sedimentation.
reasoning: Sedimentation that does not redisperse indicates protein aggregation or degradation.

narrative: The liquid in my pen has a distinctly cloudy appearance, almost like diluted milk. I checked the manual and it says the solution should be clear. I haven't used it because I'm worried it's degraded or contaminated.

When I press the button to inject, the plunger doesn't move forward. I can hear the clicking sound, but the dose counter stays at 0.5 mg and no liquid comes out of the needle. The internal mechanism seems to be disconnected.

The expiration date on the pen says 2023, but it's 2024. The pharmacy just dispensed this to me yesterday. I can't believe they gave me medication that expired a year ago. I'm taking it back immediately.

The dose selector knob is incredibly stiff. It takes two hands to turn it, and it feels like it's grinding against something inside. I'm afraid if I keep using it, the whole mechanism will just snap off.

The protective cap on my pen is damaged and I'm worried about whether the pen itself is still safe to use. The green outer cap that covers the pen and protects the mechanism has a visible crack running vertically down one side. It's not just a hairline crack - you can see it clearly and feel it with your finger. Because of this crack, the cap doesn't fit snugly onto the pen body anymore. It's loose, and when I tilt the pen or turn it upside down, the cap actually falls off. The cap is supposed to protect the pen from damage, dust, and contamination when not in use. With a cracked cap that doesn't stay on, I'm concerned that the pen mechanism could get damaged or the injection interface could get contaminated. I went back to the pharmacy to show them and they gave me a replacement pen from their stock. But get this - the replacement pen they gave me also has minor cracks in the cap, not as bad as the first one but still visible. Makes me wonder if there's a batch issue with the caps being brittle or improperly molded. The pharmacist pulled a few more from stock to check and found that several pens from the same lot had cap cracks of varying severity. They're pulling that entire lot from their shelves and reporting it to their quality team. This seems like a manufacturing defect affecting multiple units where the cap material or molding process isn't right and the caps are prone to cracking.
reasoning: Cracked protective cap across multiple units indicates manufacturing defect affecting product protection.

narrative: The cardboard tray that holds the pen inside the box was missing entirely. The pen was just rattling around loose inside the carton during shipping. The glass looks okay, but I'm worried about internal damage from all that shaking.
I bought 'generic Ozempic' from a compounding pharmacy online. It came in a vial not a pen. The label looks homemade. I'm scared to use it.
The packaging text looks blurry and the blue color is too light. The QR code goes to a 404 page. It's definitely a knock-off.
The push button is extremely hard to press. I have to use two hands to get it to move. It feels like there is too much friction in the mechanism. I can't inject properly.

I was inspecting the liquid through the window before my shot and noticed a tiny, dark speck floating around. It looks like a piece of grit or maybe a fragment of the rubber stopper. It's definitely a foreign object inside the sealed glass, and I'm not comfortable injecting it.
reasoning: Visible particulate matter in the solution.

narrative: There is a long, thin fiber—it looks like a white thread—floating inside the medication. It's definitely inside the cartridge, not on the outside of the glass. It's quite long, maybe half an inch. This is a serious quality control problem.

This is extremely concerning and I've never seen anything like it before in any medication. I was inspecting a new pen before my first dose, holding it up to the light to check that the solution is clear like you're supposed to do, and I saw what appears to be a small metallic fragment floating in the solution. It's tiny, roughly the size of a pinhead, but it's definitely metallic - looks silver or gray colored, reflects light differently than the solution, clearly not part of the liquid. When I tilt the pen back and forth, the fragment moves around and sinks or floats depending on the orientation. This is completely unexpected and honestly quite scary for an injectable medication that's supposed to be sterile. How does metal get into a sealed pharmaceutical cartridge? Could it be from the manufacturing equipment? Could it have broken off from inside the pen mechanism? I have no idea, but there's no way I'm injecting any solution that has metal particles in it. The pen is otherwise sealed, the packaging was intact, and the expiration date is still over a year away, so this isn't an issue of me damaging it or it being expired. This has to be a manufacturing contamination issue. Brought it immediately to the pharmacy and they were shocked when they saw it too. Documented everything, taking the lot number, and they're filing an urgent quality complaint with the manufacturer because metallic contamination in a sterile injectable is a critical safety issue.
reasoning: Metallic particulate contamination in sterile product is a critical quality defect.

narrative: There is a small orange particle floating in the clear liquid. It looks like plastic. It doesn't belong there. I'm afraid it will block the needle.

This is unbelievable and honestly makes me question whether I can trust this pharmacy anymore. I filled my prescription for Ozempic today, picked up the package of six pens from the pharmacy counter, drove home, and was putting them in the fridge when I happened to glance at the expiration date. Did a double take because I thought I was misreading it. The expiration date says these pens expired two months ago. Not expiring soon - already expired. Two full months past the expiration date. I immediately called the pharmacy and spoke to the pharmacist who dispensed them. She was apologetic and said it was a system error. Apparently this lot should have been flagged as expired and pulled from their active inventory, but somehow it got missed. The stock was supposedly quarantined in their system, meaning it shouldn't have been available for dispensing, but clearly something failed in their inventory controls and the expired pens got dispensed to me anyway. This is a critical failure in both inventory management and quality control. Expired medication could be less effective, potentially unsafe, and definitely shouldn't be given to patients. The pharmacist immediately pulled all remaining pens from that lot off their shelves and is investigating how it happened. They replaced my prescription with current, non-expired pens at no charge and filed an incident report. But this makes me nervous about what other errors might be happening with their inventory system.
reasoning: Dispensing expired medication indicates critical failure in inventory management and quality control.

narrative: The needle hub cracked when I tried to screw it onto the pen. I tried another needle and the same thing happened. The threads on the pen seem to be stripped or damaged. I can't attach a needle securely to inject.
reasoning: Defective pen threads preventing needle attachment.

narrative: I had a concerning problem this morning that resulted in wasted medication. I was getting ready for my weekly injection, so I screwed on a new needle to the pen and started to prepare for the dose. But before I even dialed any dose, medication started leaking out from around the rubber seal where the needle attaches to the pen. I could see drops of liquid forming at the connection point and dripping down. Probably lost about six drops before I realized what was happening and pulled the needle off. I thought maybe the needle wasn't seated properly or I'd done something wrong, so I very carefully removed it, made sure the rubber seal area was clean, got a brand new needle from the package, and screwed it on very carefully, making sure it was tight. Tried again, and the same thing happened - more leaking around the seal. The rubber seal that's supposed to create a watertight connection between the needle and the pen is either damaged or improperly formed. The seal should prevent any leakage, but clearly it's not working. With medication leaking out before I can even inject, I have no way to ensure accurate dosing. How much leaked out versus how much would actually be delivered? Can't use this pen safely. The pharmacy agreed this is a device defect with the seal and replaced the pen. They're sending the leaky one back to the manufacturer for inspection.
reasoning: Leakage at needle connection interface indicates seal defect preventing proper closure.

narrative: The pharmacy sold me expired goods. The date is from last month. This is unacceptable safety practice.

The box arrived with the cardboard tray smashed, and the pen was wedged into a corner. The glass window has a small crack in it. I'm afraid to use it because the crack might allow air or bacteria into the medication.
reasoning: Damage to primary container due to shipping.

narrative: I bought a package that comes with three pens in it because it's supposed to be more economical that way. Started using the first pen and it seemed fine, worked normally through all the doses. Opened the second pen when it was time and something looked weird right away - there's this big air gap at the top of the cartridge, like it's not filled up as much as it should be. The liquid level is noticeably lower than it was in the first pen. Used it for two doses but the air gap looks even bigger now, bigger than it should be for only two doses used. Opened the third pen to compare and that one looks normal, filled to the proper level like the first one was. So two out of three pens from the same package are completely different - one filled properly, two underfilled with excessive headspace. Either they didn't put enough medication in those two pens, or there's a leak somewhere, or the fill volume was wrong during manufacturing. Either way, I'm probably not getting the right amount of medication from those underfilled pens. Contacted the pharmacy and they're replacing the entire 3-pack. They said this is definitely a manufacturing fill or packaging defect and they're reporting it to track if other pens from that lot have the same issue.
reasoning: Underfill/abnormal headspace across units from the same pack indicates fill/packaging issue.

narrative: I found a seller on a social media marketplace offering these pens at half price. When they arrived, the box had no NDC number and the manufacturer's address was in a country I didn't recognize. The solution also has a weird chemical smell.
reasoning: Unauthorized source and multiple counterfeit signs.

narrative: Picked up my prescription from the pharmacy this afternoon and when I got home and looked at the carton before putting it in the fridge, I noticed the tamper-evident seal was already broken. You know, that clear sticker or seal that's supposed to show it hasn't been opened? It was split open, not intact like it should be. This is supposed to be a brand new, unopened product. I immediately drove back to the pharmacy and asked them about it. The pharmacist seemed surprised and apologetic, pulled up the receiving records, and said it arrived that way from their wholesaler. The whole batch or shipment apparently had issues with the tamper-evident seals already being compromised before it got to the pharmacy. She showed me other boxes from the same shipment and several of them had broken seals too. They documented everything and reported it up the chain, and obviously gave me a replacement from a different lot that had proper intact seals. But it makes you wonder - if the tamper-evident seal is broken, how can anyone guarantee that the product inside hasn't been tampered with or contaminated? That seal is there for a reason. This seems like a major packaging integrity failure somewhere in the distribution chain.
reasoning: Broken tamper evidence on unopened product is a packaging integrity defect.

narrative: I picked up my prescription today and when I got home and was looking at the carton to put it away, I noticed something that doesn't make sense. The NDC number - that's the National Drug Code number printed on the carton - doesn't match the NDC number that's printed on my prescription label from the pharmacy. They're different numbers. I called the pharmacy because this seemed wrong, and the pharmacist I spoke to kept saying that they gave me the correct product and that it matches what the doctor prescribed. But I'm looking at both numbers right now and they're definitively not the same. Different digits. This is creating a lot of confusion for me because I don't know if this is actually the right medication or the right strength. The NDC code is supposed to be a unique identifier for the specific drug and strength, so if the numbers don't match, how can I be sure this is the correct 1 mg Ozempic that my prescription calls for? Could this be a labeling error where the wrong NDC was printed on the carton? Or did the pharmacy give me the wrong product? The pharmacist seemed annoyed that I kept questioning it but this is my health we're talking about. I'm requesting they verify with the manufacturer what the correct NDC should be and replace this if there's a labeling error.
reasoning: Mismatched National Drug Code indicates labeling error that could lead to medication error.

narrative: The dose dial is stuck between numbers. It won't click into place. I can't select the correct dose.
My pharmacist noticed the lot number on the box doesn't match the lot number on the pen. The box says lot ABC and the pen says lot XYZ. They said it's a packaging mix-up and had to return it.
reasoning: Lot number mismatch between primary and secondary packaging.

narrative: The lot number is missing from the carton. The space is blank. I can't check if it's recalled. The pharmacy said it's a printing error from the manufacturer.

There's a small piece of blue plastic floating in the medication. It looks like it might have come from the cap or the internal mechanism during assembly. It's definitely a foreign object and it's large enough to see easily.
There is no expiration date printed on the pen label. The area is blank. I can see where it should be but the ink is missing. I don't know if it's safe to use.
reasoning: Missing expiration date on primary container.

narrative: So I made a mistake that I regret now. Like a lot of people, I've been frustrated with the cost and shortages of Ozempic, and when I saw an ad online for an international pharmacy offering it at like 60% off the normal price, I jumped on it. Ordered three pens, paid through some payment system I wasn't familiar with, and waited. The pens showed up after about three weeks. At first glance the packaging looks pretty genuine - has the Novo Nordisk branding, the blue pens, all of that. But when I started looking more closely, some things didn't add up. I tried scanning the 2D barcode on the box with my phone using the manufacturer's verification app, and it gave me an error message. Wouldn't scan properly or verify. Then I went to the Novo Nordisk website where they have that verification portal where you can enter the lot number, and when I put in the lot number from my pens, the system said it cannot find that lot number in their database. Like it doesn't exist in their records. And when I looked really carefully at the holographic security seal on the carton, it seems slightly misaligned or crooked, not perfectly applied like I'd expect from a professional pharmaceutical manufacturer. I showed all this to my regular pharmacist and she said these are almost certainly counterfeit and I absolutely should not use them. Multiple authentication failures plus buying from an unauthorized online source - classic red flags for fake medication. I'm out the money and learned an expensive lesson about buying prescription drugs from sketchy internet sources.
reasoning: Multiple authentication failures combined with gray-market sourcing strongly suggest counterfeit product.

narrative: I've been on this medication for months and I usually get quite nauseous after the shot, but with this new pen, I feel nothing at all. My appetite is back to normal and my blood sugar hasn't budged. I'm worried I got a batch that was sitting in a hot warehouse too long.

I've been taking my 1 mg dose for weeks but my blood sugar is climbing back up. It feels like I'm injecting water. I'm not getting the appetite suppression I usually get. I think this batch is defective or weak.
reasoning: Lack of expected therapeutic effect suggesting potency issue.

narrative: The box was soaked in water when it arrived. The cardboard is falling apart. The pens inside are wet. I don't know if the water was clean or dirty. The integrity is compromised.

The solution looks quite cloudy, almost like there's a fine dust suspended in the liquid. It's usually very clear. I haven't used it because the instructions say not to use it if it's turbid or discolored.

There are multiple issues with the packaging integrity of the pen I just received that make me question whether it's safe to use. First, the transparent plastic shrink wrap or cellophane wrapper that's supposed to be tightly sealed around the outer carton was really loose and baggy. I was able to easily slide it off without tearing anything or breaking any seal - it just slipped right off. That wrapper is supposed to be tamper-evident, so if it comes off that easily, how do I know someone hasn't already opened it? Then I opened the carton and looked at the internal blister seal - you know, that foil or plastic seal that covers the pen inside the tray. That seal was partially open at one corner. Like it had been peeled back or never fully sealed in the first place. You could actually see the edge of the pen through the gap in the seal. Between the loose outer wrapper and the compromised inner seal, the product integrity is really questionable. There's no way to be certain that this pen hasn't been tampered with, contaminated, or exposed to conditions it shouldn't have been. This is an injectable medication - sterility and integrity are absolutely critical. I took it back to the pharmacy immediately and they agreed the packaging failures are unacceptable. They documented it thoroughly, quarantined all the pens from that same lot, and are reporting it to their quality department. They gave me a replacement from a completely different lot with proper intact seals.
reasoning: Multiple compromised seals indicate packaging integrity failure affecting sterility assurance.

narrative: I screwed the needle on and tried to prime the pen like the manual says, but nothing comes out of the needle. I tried a second needle, but still no drop appears at the tip. It seems like the internal channel of the pen is blocked or not engaging with the needle.
This pen seems to have just water in it. It's clear but it has no effect. My glucose is 300. It's useless.
The injection button won't pop back out after I push it. It's stuck in the depressed position. I can't dial the next dose because it won't reset. The spring must be broken.
There is a speck of dirt inside the glass cartridge. It's dark and grainy. It's definitely inside the liquid. That's not sterile.

I received my Ozempic shipment from the mail order pharmacy and when I opened the insulated shipping container, I was hit with this strong chemical smell that definitely shouldn't be there. It smelled kind of like rubbing alcohol or disinfectant, really pungent and unpleasant. The smell was coming from inside the package, not from the outside box. When I examined the pens themselves through their sealed packaging, the cartons and pens looked normal, but that chemical odor was concerning. I'm worried that maybe the pens were exposed to some kind of cleaning chemical during storage or shipping, or that there was a spill of some kind in the warehouse that contaminated the packaging. Even though the medication is sealed inside the pen cartridge, I don't feel comfortable using product that was shipped in packaging that has such a strong chemical smell. What if whatever chemical caused that smell somehow penetrated the packaging or contaminated the exterior surfaces? I'd be handling those surfaces when preparing my injection. Called the mail order pharmacy customer service and after describing the smell, they agreed to send a replacement shipment and have me return the odorous one. They said they'd investigate whether there was a contamination incident in their distribution center. Better safe than sorry with something like this.
reasoning: Strong chemical odor from packaging suggests potential contamination during storage or shipping.

narrative: There is a grey particle in the solution. It looks like metal dust. It settles to the bottom. I'm returning it.
The medication squirted out of the side of the needle connection when I tried to inject. The needle wasn't sealing against the pen tip properly. I wasted a whole dose.
The needle won't fit on the pen. The hub is too small or the pen tip is too big. I tried multiple needles from different boxes. The pen threads are deformed.
The pharmacy sent me 3 month supply but the pens expire in 2 weeks. I can't use them all before they expire. This is a waste of money. They shouldn't dispense short-dated stock.

The box arrived with no instructions or patient info leaflet inside. The slot in the cardboard where they usually sit was just empty. As a first-time user, I really needed those documents to know how to use the pen correctly.

My mail order prescription arrived today and I could tell something was wrong before I even opened it. The outer shipping box was completely crushed on one side, like it got dropped or had something heavy placed on top of it during transit. Opened it up and the product carton inside was also dented pretty badly. The plastic tray that holds the pen was bent and when I took the pen out, it's rattling around loosely inside, like something is broken or disconnected. The green cap has a visible crack running down the side of it and doesn't stay on securely anymore. I'm really concerned about whether the internal mechanism might be damaged too, or if the cartridge seal is compromised. This is an injectable medication so integrity is really important. There's no way I'm using this pen when it's been subjected to that kind of physical trauma. I called the mail order pharmacy right away and they're sending a replacement overnight, but they said I need to send back the damaged one with photos for their quality records. It's frustrating because this is the second time I've had issues with their packaging and shipping methods. They need to use better protective packaging for fragile medical devices.
reasoning: Physical damage to carton and device indicates packaging integrity failure.

narrative: I made a careless mistake and I'm really upset with myself. I travel for work and I keep my Ozempic in a small insulated travel case so I can take it with me. Last week I was rushing to catch a flight and I put the case in my car trunk instead of bringing it into the house. Then I completely forgot about it. This happened to be during a cold snap we had, with overnight temperatures dropping down to around 20 degrees Fahrenheit. The pens were in my car trunk for three full days in subfreezing temperatures before I remembered and went to retrieve them. When I opened the case and looked at the pens, I could see that the solution was partially frozen - there were visible ice crystals inside the cartridge when I held it up to the window. I brought them inside and let them thaw completely at room temperature. Once thawed, the solution looks clear again and the ice crystals are gone, but I know from the storage instructions that Ozempic should never be frozen. Even if it looks normal after thawing, freezing can denature the protein and make the medication ineffective or unreliable. I called my doctor's office and the nurse confirmed I need to throw these pens away and get new ones. Can't use medication that's been frozen even though it looks okay now. So I'm out two pens because of my own mistake. Just documenting this in case anyone else accidentally freezes their medication - don't try to use it even after it thaws.
reasoning: Freezing exposure violates storage conditions and likely denatures the protein therapeutic.

narrative: The text on the pen is blurry. I can't read the dose window markings. The printing is bad quality.

The ice packs in my mail-order shipment were actually still frozen solid, but they were placed directly against the pens without any padding. The liquid in the pens was frozen into a slushy ice. I know you're not supposed to freeze this stuff, so I'm assuming it's ruined.

The National Drug Code (NDC) on the pen doesn't match the one on the box. They are close, but the last few digits are different. This makes me worry that the wrong medication or the wrong strength was put in this box.

The dial on my pen is stuck at the 0.25 mg mark and won't turn any further. I've tried twisting it gently and then more firmly, but it's completely jammed. It feels like something is caught in the internal gears of the device.

I was doing my usual check of the pen before using it and noticed that the lot number printed on the actual pen body is really smudged, like the ink was smeared or something. I can maybe make out a couple digits but most of it is completely unreadable. And then I looked for the expiration date on the device itself and it's just not there at all. Like, it's missing entirely from the pen body. The outer carton has all the information - lot number, expiration date, everything is printed clearly on the box - but the device itself doesn't have readable traceability information. My understanding is that this information is supposed to be on both the carton and the device for safety reasons, so you can always verify what you're using even if you throw away the box. I need to be able to track which specific pen I'm using in case there's ever a recall or quality issue, and right now I can't do that because the pen itself can't be verified or traced. I contacted the pharmacy to let them know, and they're documenting this issue. They confirmed the lot number from the carton for my records, but this seems like a labeling defect that should be reported.
reasoning: Missing/illegible critical traceability data on the device is a labeling defect.

narrative: There are blue plastic shavings floating in the solution. It looks like debris from the pen manufacturing. It's definitely foreign material.

When I try to screw the needle onto the pen, it won't lock into place. It just keeps spinning and spinning as if the threads are stripped. I've tried multiple needles from the same box, so it must be the threads on the pen itself that are defective.
reasoning: Defective device threads preventing needle attachment.

narrative: When I try to press the injection button, it's completely stuck. I've tried pushing it with both thumbs as hard as I can, but it won't move even a millimeter. The pen is totally unusable because of this mechanical jam.
I found a hair inside the sealed blister pack with the pen. It was stuck to the side of the pen. It's disgusting. How does that happen in a sterile manufacturing facility?

Medication is leaking out of the back of the pen, near the dose counter, whenever I press the button. It seems like an internal seal has failed and the liquid is taking the path of least resistance out the wrong end of the device.
reasoning: Internal seal failure leading to backward leakage.

narrative: The liquid in the pen cartridge has a cloudy, suspension-like appearance. It's not clear at all. It looks more like milk than the clear water-like liquid I'm used to. I haven't used it because the manual says it must be clear.

I was checking the liquid before my injection and saw a tiny black speck—maybe a piece of dust or plastic—floating right near the center of the cartridge. I'm definitely not injecting anything with visible particles in it.

I bought this pen from an online 'health store' that didn't require a prescription. Now that I have it, the holographic seal on the box looks like a cheap sticker, and the font is slightly different from the pens I get at my local CVS. I'm starting to think this isn't the real medication.
The plunger is already halfway down the cartridge on a new pen. It looks like it's been used but the seal was intact. Is it underfilled? I'm missing doses.

I can see what looks like a tiny bit of red plastic floating in the medication liquid. It's very small but definitely noticeable through the pen window. It looks like it might have come from the manufacturing machinery.
The rubber stopper at the end of the cartridge is crooked. It's not sitting flat. I'm worried it won't push the liquid out evenly. It looks like a manufacturing defect.

Okay, so this is embarrassing but I need to report it because I think I got counterfeit Ozempic and others need to be warned. I was scrolling through social media, I think it was Instagram or TikTok, and I saw an advertisement for a pharmacy claiming to sell Ozempic without requiring a prescription. Red flag number one, I know. But they were offering it for much cheaper than my copay, and they claimed to be based overseas where the regulations are different. Against my better judgment, I ordered from them. The pens arrived after five weeks - no tracking, no temperature control packaging, just showed up one day in my mailbox. When I opened it and looked at the product, so many things were wrong. The carton has multiple spelling errors in the text - like medication spelled wrong, instructions with grammar problems. The pen cap is this weird off-blue color, not the proper shade it should be. And when I held up the pen to check the solution, it has a faint yellowish tint instead of being crystal clear. My regular pharmacist took one look at it and said it's obviously counterfeit or diverted product. No legitimate pharmacy sells prescription medication without a prescription. No real manufacturer has misspellings on their packaging. The wrong cap color, the discolored solution - all signs of fake product. I'm out the money I paid, and I'm reporting this to the FDA because other people are probably falling for the same scam. Don't buy prescription drugs from social media ads or unauthorized online sellers.
reasoning: No prescription requirement, poor shipping, visual defects, and misspellings indicate counterfeit product.

narrative: I pushed the button to inject but no liquid came out. The counter went down to 0, but I didn't feel the injection and there was no drop on the needle tip. I checked the flow and nothing is coming out. It's clogged.
reasoning: Failure to deliver dose despite counter movement.

narrative: I'm reporting what I believe to be diverted or possibly counterfeit Ozempic that I unfortunately purchased. I was looking for better prices and found an online seller advertising bulk discounts - offering twelve pens at a significant savings if you bought in quantity. They claimed to ship from Canada to the US, which I thought was legal for personal use. Placed an order and the pens arrived a few weeks later. As soon as I opened the package, I knew something was off. All the labeling is in French only, no English at all. The box design looks similar to Ozempic packaging but the colors and layout are slightly different from what I'm used to. The color scheme doesn't match the FDA-approved packaging I've seen before. I tried looking up the NDC number online and it returns no results in the US database - like the code doesn't exist in our system. My regular pharmacist looked at it and immediately said this is likely diverted product from the Canadian market that's not approved for sale in the US. Different packaging, different regulatory approval, possibly different manufacturing standards or quality oversight. Or it could be counterfeit made to look like Canadian product. Either way, she strongly advised not to use it and to report the seller. The medication came from an unauthorized distribution channel and doesn't meet US regulatory requirements. I'm out the money and learned a hard lesson about buying prescription drugs from random online sellers offering bulk discounts.
reasoning: Foreign-labeled product with unapproved packaging from unauthorized channel indicates diversion or counterfeit.

narrative: The outer carton was soaked in some kind of oily liquid when I picked it up. It doesn't smell like the medicine, so I think something else leaked onto it during shipping. The pens inside seem okay, but the packaging is ruined.

The box arrived crushed and open. The tamper seal was broken. The pen was rolling around loose inside the shipping envelope. I don't know if it's been tampered with or if it's sterile. I can't use this.

My shipment arrived today and the box was sopping wet. One of the ice packs had burst and leaked all over the medication boxes. The cardboard is falling apart and I'm worried the moisture might have gotten into the pens or compromised the sterility.
reasoning: Packaging failure leading to potential damage.

narrative: The box arrived with the top flap missing and the inner tray was loose inside the mailing envelope. The pen was rolling around without any protection. I don't think the product's integrity can be guaranteed after that.

The needle snapped off right at the hub while I was trying to screw it onto the pen. The metal part just fell out of the plastic. I'm lucky I wasn't already injecting, or the needle would have been stuck in my skin.
The package tracking said delivered 3 days ago but I just got it. It's been lost in the mail. The ice packs are warm room temperature. The medication is spoiled.
reasoning: Shipping delay leading to temperature excursion.

narrative: The liquid is cloudy and thick. It's not flowing right. It looks like it curdled. It's definitely bad.

I opened a new pen yesterday and was doing my routine inspection before the first use, and something about the solution just doesn't look right to me. It appears slightly cloudy, not crystal clear like all my previous pens have been. And there are these tiny bubbles throughout the liquid - really small ones, but definitely there. I let the pen sit upright in the fridge overnight thinking maybe the bubbles would rise to the top and dissipate, you know, like sometimes happens when you first open something. But this morning when I checked it again, the cloudiness is still there and the bubbles haven't gone away at all. All my previous pens from other lots have been perfectly clear and colorless. This one just looks different. The solution might still be okay, but the instructions say it should be clear and the visual appearance is supposed to be checked before each use. Since this one doesn't match what I'm used to seeing and doesn't match the description in the instructions, I don't feel comfortable using it. Contacted the pharmacy and they agreed the appearance sounds abnormal and are replacing it. Better safe than sorry when it comes to injectable medications. They're sending the pen back to the manufacturer to check whether it's a stability issue or contamination or what.
reasoning: Cloudiness suggests instability/precipitation inconsistent with labeled appearance.

narrative: Medication is leaking out from the side of the pen body, not the needle, whenever I apply pressure. There must be a crack in the internal housing or a failed seal somewhere inside. It's getting all over my hands instead of going into my skin.

My prescription was supposed to be for the 2 mg pens since I've been titrated up to that maintenance dose, but when I got home and looked carefully at what the pharmacy gave me, I realized something was wrong. The prescription label that the pharmacy printed and stuck on the box says 2 mg, but the actual manufacturer's carton inside says 1 mg. The pen itself also shows 1 mg on the device label. So the pharmacy's system thought they were dispensing 2 mg and that's what they labeled it as, but the actual product in the bag is 1 mg. This is a potentially serious medication error - if I hadn't noticed and had taken my prescribed 2 mg dose using the 1 mg pen thinking it was the right strength, I would have been underdosed. That could affect my blood sugar control and the therapeutic effects I'm supposed to be getting. I immediately went back to the pharmacy to correct this error. The pharmacist apologized profusely and said they must have grabbed the wrong product from the shelf when filling my prescription. Their barcode scanning system should have caught the mismatch, but apparently it didn't. They gave me the correct 2 mg pens and are investigating why their verification system failed to catch the wrong strength. This is scary because if their checking systems aren't working properly, how many other patients are getting the wrong medications or wrong strengths?
reasoning: Mismatch between pharmacy-applied label and actual product strength creates medication error risk.

narrative: There is a piece of cardboard inside the blister pack. It's clean but it shouldn't be there. It's foreign material.

I can see what looks like a tiny bit of black rubber floating in the cartridge. It looks exactly like the material of the stopper. Maybe the needle sliced a piece off when I inserted it, but it's now floating in the main reservoir.
reasoning: Fragment of internal component in solution.

narrative: My blood sugar is back to pre-medication levels since I started using this new box of pens. The only thing that changed is this new prescription lot. I suspect the concentration of the medication is way below what it should be.
reasoning: Significant clinical failure suggesting potency issues.

narrative: I made a really stupid mistake and I'm not sure what to do now. I keep my Ozempic pen at my office so I can take it after lunch, and I have this little mini-fridge under my desk where I store it. Yesterday afternoon I was rearranging some stuff and I guess I accidentally put the pen in the small freezer compartment instead of the regular fridge part. Didn't realize my mistake until this morning when I went to check on it and found it sitting in the freezer section. It had been in there for probably 24 hours. The solution was actually partially frozen - I could see it wasn't fully solid but definitely had ice in it. I took it out and let it thaw at room temperature for a few hours, and now the solution looks clear again, no crystals or anything visible. Called the pharmacist to ask if it's still safe to use and she said absolutely not, that freezing the medication destroys it and I need to throw it away and get a new one. Something about the protein structure being damaged by freezing even if it looks normal after thawing. So now I'm out a pen because of my own carelessness. Just want to document what happened in case anyone else makes the same mistake - don't use it after freezing even if it looks okay.
reasoning: Freezing violates storage conditions and may denature the product.

narrative: There's a small piece of dark material floating in the pen that looks like a fragment of wood or cardboard. I don't know how it got in there, but it's definitely not part of the medication. I'm returning it to the pharmacy.

I ordered this from a site that claimed to sell the name brand at a steep discount. Now that I have it, the logo is slightly blurry and the security hologram doesn't change color. I'm pretty sure I received a counterfeit product.
reasoning: Counterfeit indicators on packaging and suspicious source.

narrative: My delivery arrived while I was at work, and the courier left it on the front steps in direct sunlight. By the time I got home and opened the box, the internal temperature indicator had turned dark red, and the pens felt warm to the touch. The ice packs had completely liquified and were room temperature.
There is a hair trapped in the glass of the cartridge. It's embedded in the wall. Manufacturing defect.
I bought this from a friend who said they didn't need it anymore. The box is open and some pens are missing. I don't know how it was stored. I'm worried it might be tampered with.
I suspect these pens are counterfeit. The packaging looks low quality and the colors are off. The QR code on the side doesn't scan. The price was too good to be true.
reasoning: Visual discrepancies and scan failure indicating counterfeit.

narrative: Just opened a brand new, completely sealed Ozempic pen that I picked up from the pharmacy three days ago, and I'm really alarmed by what I'm seeing. The solution inside has this brownish or amber color to it, running throughout the entire cartridge. It definitely should be clear and colorless according to the instructions and compared to all the pens I've used before. This isn't just a slight tint - it's noticeably brown, like a light tea color or something. The pen has been stored properly in my refrigerator at the correct temperature since I brought it home from the pharmacy, so this discoloration isn't from improper storage on my end. The seal was intact when I opened it, so it's not contamination from outside. This has to be either degradation or contamination that happened during manufacturing or storage before it got to me. I made sure to write down and save the lot number from the carton before calling the pharmacy. They said absolutely don't use it, brown or amber color is definitely abnormal and could indicate the product has degraded or gone bad somehow. They're having me return it so they can send it back to the manufacturer for investigation. I'm concerned about what caused this and whether other pens from the same batch have the same problem.
reasoning: Brown/amber color is abnormal for semaglutide solution and suggests degradation or contamination.

narrative: I checked the QR code on the box with my phone and it took me to a website that doesn't belong to the manufacturer. It looks like a fake site designed to look official. This definitely isn't legitimate medication.
reasoning: Fake verification site confirming counterfeit product.

narrative: The solution in this pen is not clear. It has a foggy, hazy appearance. It's supposed to be transparent. I compared it to my last pen and the difference is obvious. I'm returning it.
I put the pen in the freezer by mistake. I thawed it out but it looks cloudy. The instructions say discard if frozen. I have to throw it away.

I had a really weird and concerning experience with my injection yesterday. I very carefully set the dose to exactly 0.5 mg on the dial like I always do - I'm meticulous about this because I know dosing accuracy is important. Attached the needle, did the injection into my abdomen like normal, pressed the button all the way down and held it for the count. But while I was doing it, something felt off. The plunger barely seemed to move, like the injection was over really quick. When I looked at the dose counter after removing the needle, it had only decreased by maybe 0.1 mg worth, definitely not the full 0.5 mg I had dialed. So either the medication didn't come out, or there's something wrong with the mechanism. I ended up having to dial another 0.4 mg or so and inject again, then check, and had to do this like three or four times total before it finally seemed like I'd gotten the full dose. This is very concerning because I have no idea if I'm actually getting accurate dosing from this pen. Is it under-delivering each time? Is the plunger movement indicator broken but the dose is actually correct? I can't tell, and that's a safety issue. The pharmacy had me bring in the pen and they're sending it to the manufacturer for testing because if the dose delivery mechanism isn't working correctly, that's a serious defect. I'm worried about whether I've been getting my full prescribed doses from this pen.
reasoning: Under-delivery of dialed dose suggests mechanism failure affecting potency/dose accuracy.

narrative: The solution in my pen has turned a weird pinkish color. It's supposed to be clear. I've kept it in the fridge the whole time. I'm afraid to use it because it looks contaminated or spoiled. Is this safe?

The lot number on the box is different from the lot number on the pen. One says batch 4455, the other says batch 4456. This makes it impossible to know which batch this medication actually belongs to if there's a recall.
I ordered Ozempic but received a box of Saxenda instead. The pharmacy mixed up the order. The label on the bag has my name and Ozempic, but the box is Saxenda.
reasoning: Pharmacy dispensing error - wrong product distributed.

narrative: My pen broke in half when I took the cap off. The plastic snapped right at the threads. The cartridge fell out and smashed on the floor. The plastic felt very brittle.

This pen is dated to expire in exactly 4 days. I'm supposed to use it for the next 4 weeks. By the time I take my second dose, it will already be past the manufacturer's safety date. The pharmacy shouldn't be giving out stock this old.
reasoning: Inappropriate shelf life for prescription duration.

narrative: I was preparing to do my injection yesterday evening and noticed the plunger inside the pen cartridge appears to be stuck or jammed in place. I can see through the window that there's still medication in the cartridge - probably three or four doses worth based on the liquid level - but the plunger isn't moving at all when I try to dial or inject. The dose selector turns and clicks normally, the injection button depresses, but nothing happens with the actual plunger mechanism. It's like the plunger is frozen in position and won't advance to push the medication out. I've tried everything I can think of - letting it warm up to room temperature in case the cold affected it, gently tapping the pen, checking for any visible obstructions - nothing works. The internal drive mechanism that's supposed to move the plunger forward must be broken or disconnected somehow. This happened after I'd only used two doses from this pen, so there should be at least four more doses remaining that I now can't access. The medication is right there in the cartridge, I can see it, but there's no way to get it out because the delivery mechanism is completely jammed. Pharmacy confirmed this is a device malfunction with the plunger drive system and replaced the pen. They're reporting it to the manufacturer as a mechanical failure that prevented dose delivery.
reasoning: Jammed plunger mechanism preventing medication delivery indicates internal mechanical failure.
