narrative: The pen looks fake. The blue is the wrong shade. The plastic feels cheap. The label is crooked. It's a counterfeit.

There's a bunch of tiny white crystals sitting at the bottom of the pen cartridge. I tried rolling it between my palms to see if they'd dissolve, but they didn't budge. The liquid isn't a uniform solution anymore.
The pen cap is cracked down the side and won't stay on. It falls off in my bag. The needle attachment part is exposed to dirt. It was like this when I took it out of the box.

The expiration date on the pen itself is missing. The space where it's supposed to be printed is just a blank white box. The outer carton has a date, but I need to be able to verify it on the actual device for safety.
reasoning: Missing critical labeling information on the device.

narrative: I've been using Ozempic for about six months now without any issues, but this new pen I started this week is giving me problems. When I try to dial up my dose to 0.75 mg like I'm supposed to, the dose knob gets really stiff and jams right at that point. Won't turn any further no matter what I do. I have to use quite a bit of force to try to rotate it, and when I do manage to move it slightly, it just slips back to a lower number. I thought maybe I was just having an off day, so I tried again this morning with my reading glasses on to make sure I was doing it right - same problem. Then my next scheduled dose came up and I opened my second pen from the same box, and would you believe it's doing the exact same thing? Both pens from the same lot number are jamming at 0.75 mg. I can dial to 0.5 mg fine, but can't get to the dose I need. Called the manufacturer's help line and they're sending me a report form to fill out. Meanwhile I had to go back on my previous lower dose until I can get working pens. Both of these are from lot number XK4892.
reasoning: Mechanical failure of dose selector across multiple units points to device malfunction.

narrative: I received these from an overseas pharmacy that didn't ask for a prescription. The label has numerous typos and the holographic seal looks like it was printed on a regular inkjet printer. I suspect these are fakes.
reasoning: Counterfeit indicators and unauthorized supply channel.

narrative: There is a piece of metal wire inside the cartridge. It looks like a staple. It's rusting in the liquid. This is dangerous contamination.
The dose selector dial feels gritty and makes a grinding noise. It's hard to turn. It feels like there is sand inside the mechanism. I'm worried it will jam.
The dose window is foggy and I can't read the numbers. It looks like moisture got inside the mechanism. I can't set the dose accurately because I can't see the lines.
reasoning: Unreadable dose window due to fogging.

narrative: This was alarming when I discovered it. I opened the package with my new pen, removed it from the tray, and took off the green outer cap to inspect it before first use like I'm supposed to. That's when I noticed that the rubber seal that's supposed to be under the cap, covering the pen tip, is completely missing. Just not there at all. The pen tip where you screw on the needle was totally exposed, no protective barrier covering it. That seal is supposed to be there to maintain sterility of the injection interface until you're ready to use the pen, and mine didn't have one. This seems like a serious sterility issue because that's the exact area where the needle attaches and where the medication comes out. If it was exposed during shipping and handling without that protective seal, there's no way to guarantee it's still sterile. I mean, any dust, bacteria, contaminants could have gotten on that surface. I absolutely cannot use this pen when the sterility of the injection point is compromised. Brought it back to the pharmacy immediately and they agreed this is a critical packaging component failure. They documented it thoroughly, gave me a replacement from a different lot that has the proper seal intact, and are sending the defective one back to the manufacturer. This kind of missing component is unacceptable for injectable medication packaging.
reasoning: Missing seal component compromises sterility of the injection interface and represents critical packaging failure.

narrative: There is oil separation in the liquid. It looks like salad dressing that needs shaking. It's supposed to be a uniform solution. Something is wrong with the formulation.
The liquid is amber colored, like apple juice. It smells funny too. It's definitely not right. I think it has degraded from heat or something. I'm returning it.
The liquid has separated into layers. Oil and water. It shouldn't look like that. It's spoiled.
I left the package in my trunk for 2 days in the summer heat. The liquid is hot. The plastic pen feels soft. I messed up and ruined the medication.

Had a frustrating experience trying to use my new pen for the first time. The green outer cap that covers the pen was on so tight that I literally could not remove it by hand. I tried twisting, pulling, using a rubber grip, nothing worked. It was stuck on there incredibly tight. Eventually I had to get a pair of pliers from my toolbox and use those to grip the cap and twist it off, which should obviously not be necessary for a medical device. But here's the problem - when I applied the force needed with the pliers to get the cap off, I heard a small cracking sound and now there's a visible hairline crack in the clear plastic pen body near the window where you see the solution. I'm really concerned that the excessive force required to remove the cap may have damaged the internal mechanism or compromised the seal integrity of the cartridge. Can I still safely use this pen or is the crack going to affect how it works or potentially cause leakage? The pharmacy said to bring it in and they'll replace it because a cap should never be that difficult to remove and requiring tools to open it is definitely an assembly or manufacturing defect. Makes me wonder if the cap was somehow cross-threaded or over-tightened during assembly.
reasoning: Cap removal requiring excessive force and causing damage indicates assembly or component defect.

narrative: I injected the full dose but I felt nothing. Usually it stings a little. My blood sugar didn't change at all. I wonder if it's just saline in the pen.

This is an unfortunate situation caused by a delivery error that resulted in my medication being left unrefrigerated for way too long. I use a specialty pharmacy for my Ozempic and they shipped it via overnight delivery in an insulated package with ice packs like they're supposed to. The tracking showed it was out for delivery yesterday morning and marked as delivered at 10 AM. But I never received it. Turns out the courier mis-delivered it to my neighbor's house two doors down instead of mine. My neighbor has an enclosed front porch that isn't visible from the street, so they didn't notice the package sitting there until this morning when they were leaving for work. They brought it over to me, which was nice of them, but by then it had been sitting on their enclosed porch for almost two full days. When I felt the package, it was room temperature or even warmer - remember, it's been sitting in an enclosed porch for 48 hours. Opened it up and the ice packs were completely thawed, just bags of warm water at this point. Based on the timeline, this medication has been unrefrigerated in a warm environment for approximately 48 hours. The storage requirements say it needs to be refrigerated and shouldn't be exposed to temperatures above 86 degrees for extended periods. I have no idea what temperature it reached sitting in that enclosed porch, but it's definitely been compromised. Called the specialty pharmacy and they're sending a replacement at no charge, but this is a waste of medication due to a delivery error. They said I should not use the mis-delivered pens since the temperature excursion was so prolonged.
reasoning: Two-day unrefrigerated storage due to delivery failure constitutes temperature excursion.

narrative: The glass cartridge is shattered inside the pen holder. I can hear the glass rattling. Liquid is leaking out the bottom.

My refrigerator's thermostat failed while I was away for the weekend, and the temperature inside went up to 75 degrees. My Ozempic pens were in there the whole time. I don't know how many hours they were sitting at room temperature, but it's been at least two days.
I took the shot but felt no resistance. It was too easy. I don't think it injected anything. The pen is defective.
reasoning: Injection mechanism failure - no resistance indicates plunger/delivery mechanism defect.

narrative: The liquid has a faint yellowish tint to it today. I checked my other pens and they are all crystal clear. This discoloration makes me think the medicine has degraded or was exposed to light or heat for too long.
The delivery box was sitting in the sun. The ice pack was warm water. The pens were hot. They shouldn't leave medication in the sun.

I just opened a brand new Ozempic pen and I'm shocked by what I'm seeing. The solution inside appears milky white instead of clear and colorless like it's supposed to be. It literally looks like diluted milk or a suspension of some kind. This is completely abnormal. I've been using Ozempic for six months now and all my previous pens have had perfectly clear, water-like solution with no color or cloudiness at all. To make sure I wasn't going crazy, I pulled out my almost-empty pen from last week and compared them side by side. The old pen is crystal clear and the new pen is definitely milky white. Both pens have been stored under identical conditions in my refrigerator at the proper temperature, so this isn't a storage issue on my end. A milky appearance in a solution that should be clear indicates either protein aggregation, where the medication molecules are clumping together, or possibly even microbial contamination. Either way, this is a critical quality issue. There's no way I'm injecting this into my body. I wrote down the lot number from the carton before I called the pharmacy. They agreed that milky white appearance is definitely abnormal and potentially dangerous. They're having me return the pen so it can be sent to the manufacturer's quality lab for investigation. They need to figure out what caused this appearance change and whether it's an isolated issue or if other pens from that batch are affected.
reasoning: Milky appearance indicates protein aggregation or microbial contamination—critical quality issue.

narrative: I was getting ready to take my very first dose of Ozempic today, so I followed the instructions exactly like it says in the booklet. I attached the needle, did the priming procedure, turned the dial to release the air and prime it, heard the clicking sound like it's supposed to make, but then nothing. No drop appeared at the needle tip at all. So I thought maybe it was the needle, took it off, put on a brand new one from the pack, tried again. Same thing. Clicked, but no medication came out. I probably tried this about five or six times with two different needles and I'm getting nowhere. The mechanism inside seems to be working - I can hear the clicks, the dial turns, but it's like the medication just won't flow through. Something must be blocked inside the pen. I called the pharmacy and they said this shouldn't happen and to bring it back for a replacement. Really frustrating because I was supposed to start my treatment today and now I have to wait.
reasoning: Failure to prime/deliver dose suggests internal blockage or mechanism failure in the prefilled pen.

narrative: There's a confusing and potentially dangerous mismatch between what's printed on the carton and what's actually on the pen device. The outer carton clearly states that the pen contains 4 doses at 0.25 mg each. That's what it says right on the label. But when I look at the actual pen dose selector dial, the markings only show 0.5 mg and 1 mg dose options. There's no 0.25 mg marking anywhere on the dial that I can see. This is a major problem because my prescription specifically requires that I start at the lower 0.25 mg dose for the first four weeks as a titration period before increasing. If the pen doesn't have 0.25 mg markings, how am I supposed to take that dose? Did they package the wrong pen in this carton? Is the carton labeling wrong? I have no idea but the carton description and the actual device don't match up. I went back to the pharmacy to confirm I wasn't missing something, and the pharmacist looked at it and agreed there's definitely a mismatch - the carton says one thing and the pen shows another. She checked other pens in stock and they all had the correct dose markings that matched their cartons. So mine is some kind of labeling error or packaging mix-up. They swapped it out for a correctly labeled and marked pen. But this is a serious issue because if someone didn't notice and tried to use it, they'd end up taking the wrong dose.
reasoning: Inconsistency between labeled dose availability and actual device markings.

narrative: The pharmacy is trying to sell me pens that expire in 10 days. I need a supply that lasts for at least a month. They told me 'it's all they have', but I'm not paying for medicine that will be officially expired halfway through my treatment.
reasoning: Supply of medication with inadequate remaining shelf life.

narrative: I've been on this medication for three months and it's worked great, but this new batch doesn't seem to do anything. My blood sugar numbers are way up and I'm feeling hungry all the time again. It feels like there's no medicine in these pens.
reasoning: Lack of therapeutic effect suggesting poor potency.

narrative: The drug seems weak. I'm not getting the benefits. My hunger is back. I think the concentration is wrong.
The delivery truck had no AC. The box was scorching hot. The medication is cooked. It needs to be refrigerated.

There's an oily film on the surface of the liquid inside the pen window. It looks like a rainbow sheen, similar to oil on water. It doesn't look like a consistent, clear medication. I'm worried the ingredients have separated.
The pen feels very light, like it's empty. I can see liquid but maybe it's not full. I weighed it compared to my old one and it's lighter. I think it's underfilled.
The injection button broke off. It just snapped. Now I can't push the plunger. The plastic is very weak.

I've been on Ozempic for over a year now and I know what the packaging should look like, so when I picked up this refill something immediately seemed off to me. The pen cap color is different - it's still blue but it's like a slightly different shade, not quite the same as all my previous pens. And the font used for the printing on the pen looks different too, like maybe a different typeface or size. Then I looked at the lot code on the carton and that font also seems inconsistent with what I'm used to seeing. The numbers look lighter or thinner somehow. Being suspicious at this point, I tried scanning the QR code with my phone to verify authenticity on the manufacturer's website like they tell you to do, and it's giving me an error message. Either the code isn't valid or it's not linking to the Novo Nordisk site like it should. I still have an empty pen from my last prescription and I compared them side by side - definitely differences in appearance. Called the pharmacy right away and they pulled my last prescription's info to compare lot numbers and packaging. They agreed something doesn't look right and they're investigating with their wholesaler. They gave me a different pen from a different batch in the meantime and that one looks correct. Really concerning that potentially counterfeit or diverted product could make it into the legitimate supply chain.
reasoning: Appearance inconsistencies and failed verification point to potential counterfeit/diverted product.

narrative: The refrigerator broke while I was on vacation. The temperature went up to 80 degrees for a week. The pens were warm. I know they aren't good anymore.

I bought this online from a Canadian pharmacy site because it was cheaper. The box arrived and all the writing is in a foreign language, maybe Turkish? The pen looks slightly different than my usual ones. I suspect it might be fake or diverted.
reasoning: Foreign labeling and suspicious source suggesting counterfeit/diversion.

narrative: There is a small black particle floating in the liquid. It looks like a piece of rubber stopper. It moves around when I shake the pen. I'm not going to inject that into my body. This is a quality control failure.
reasoning: Visible particulate matter (rubber) in sterile solution.

narrative: The label on my pen says it's the 0.5 mg strength, but the box it came in is clearly labeled as 1 mg. This is a huge mismatch and could have led to a serious dosing error if I hadn't double-checked everything before use.
reasoning: Strength mismatch between carton and pen device.

narrative: I can see a tiny silver sliver—it looks like a piece of metal—floating in the liquid inside the pen window. I'm worried it's a piece of the manufacturing equipment that broke off during the filling process.
The box says 1.0 mg dose, but the pen inside has markings for only 0.25 and 0.5 mg. I can't take my full prescribed dose with this device. It's clearly the wrong pen in the wrong box.
The dial made a loud cracking sound when I was turning it, and now it just spins freely without changing the dose numbers. I can't set my 0.5 mg dose because the internal gears must have snapped.
reasoning: Mechanical breakage of the dial mechanism.

narrative: The dosage instructions on the pen label are printed in Spanish, but I'm in an English-speaking region and the box is in English. This mix-up is very confusing and I'm not sure if the concentration is the same as what I usually get.

The instructions for use inside the box are for a completely different medication—something called Victoza. The box and the pen say Ozempic, but the booklet is wrong. If I followed these instructions, I might have used the device incorrectly.

This is really disturbing. I was inspecting a new pen before first use like I always do, holding it up to the light to check that the solution is clear, and I saw what looks like a black speck or particle floating in the cartridge. It's small, maybe about a millimeter in size, but definitely visible and very dark, almost black, against the clear solution. It's floating freely in the liquid and moves around when I tilt the pen. This pen has never been opened or used - it's brand new, still sealed in the original packaging. The presence of any kind of particulate matter in a sterile injectable medication is totally unacceptable. This is supposed to be a sterile product and there should be nothing floating in it. I took the pen directly to the pharmacy to show them. The pharmacist looked at it under their magnifying light and agreed it's definitely a foreign particle of some kind. She immediately documented everything, took pictures, recorded the lot number, and replaced the pen with one from a different batch. She said they'll be sending this one back to the manufacturer and filing a contamination report. This is a serious quality control issue because that particle could have been injected into someone if they didn't inspect the pen carefully first. Makes me wonder about the sterility and manufacturing conditions if stuff like this is getting through.
reasoning: Visible particulate matter in sterile injectable product represents serious contamination risk.

narrative: My pharmacy just told me they had to pull all the pens from the lot I was dispensed last week because they were found to be past their 'use by' date. They want me to bring them back for a swap. It's a major distribution error.
The solution has crystals in it that look like shards of glass. They are settling at the bottom. I've never seen this before. I'm afraid it will clog the needle or hurt me.
